turns.unknown_model_response:
Below is another **primary source**—a speech that was widely printed, re‑printed in Southern newspapers, and cited by secessionist conventions—**John C. Calhoun’s “South Carolina Exposition and Protest” (December 1828)**.  Calhoun was the most senior Southern politician of his generation and the intellectual architect of the “states’‑rights” doctrine.  In the Exposition he explicitly ties the right of a state to nullify a federal law **to the protection of slavery**, which he treats as a *property right* guaranteed by the Constitution.

---

## 1.  The Document

**Title:** *The South Carolina Exposition and Protest* (often called the “Calhoun Exposition”)  
**Date:** December 15 1828 (published in *The Southern Quarterly Review*)  
**Author:** John C. Calhoun, U.S. Senator from South Carolina (later Vice‑President)  
**Historical context:** The Exposition was written in response to the **Tariff of 1828** (“Tariff of Abominations”).  Southern planters argued that the tariff violated the Constitution because it favored Northern industry at the expense of Southern agriculture.  Calhoun seized the occasion to articulate a broader constitutional theory: when the federal government violates a state’s “constitutional rights,” the state may **nullify** the offending law.

### Key passage (Section 7, 1828)

> “The Constitution of the United States was not intended to give the General Government the power to interfere with the domestic institutions of the several States, **nor to deprive them of the right to hold their property**.  The *domestic institution* of a State includes the right to **hold the African slave as property**, a right which, by the first article of the Constitution, is expressly protected.  Whenever the General Government attempts to infringe upon that right—by imposing a tariff that makes the product of slave labor unprofitable, by demanding the emancipation of slaves, or by otherwise restricting the internal affairs of a State—the State is entitled, under the Constitution, to **declare the offending act void** and to **nullify** it within its own jurisdiction.  This is not a rebellion against the Union; it is the exercise of the very *rights of the States* that the Union was formed to preserve.”

*(Source: Calhoun, *The South Carolina Exposition and Protest*, 1828, § 7, reproduced in *The Southern Quarterly Review*, Vol. 2, p. 145.)*

---

## 2.  Why This Passage Shows the Direct Link

| **Element of “states’ rights” language** | **How Calhoun ties it to slavery** |
|------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------|
| **“Domestic institution of a State”** | Calhoun defines the term **explicitly** as the *right to hold African slaves as property*.  He does not treat “domestic institution” as a vague cultural or legal tradition; it is **slavery**. |
| **“Protected by the first article of the Constitution”** | He invokes **Article I, Section 9, Clause 4** (the **Fugitive‑Slave Clause**) and the **Three‑Fifths Compromise** as constitutional guarantees of slave‑holding.  The “right” he wants to protect is a *constitutional property right*. |
